_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The qualities of each kind of wealth [an: Faith in the Realized One’s awakening
Not killing living creatures, not stealing, not committing sexual misconduct, not using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical, not consuming alcoholic drinks that cause negligence
Having a conscience, being conscientious about bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and conscientious about having any bad, unskillful qualities
Being prudent, being prudent when it comes to bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and prudent when it comes to the acquiring of any bad, unskillful qualities

Being very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned, being learned in teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure
Living at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share
Having the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
